prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Characters:
Character 0
Name: Maya Fey
Description: My assistant and a disciple in the Kurain tradition of spirit channeling.
Character 1
Name: Dick Gumshoe
Description: Detective at the local precinct. In charge of the initial investigation.
Character 2
Name: Franziska von Karma
Description: A prosecutor in Germany since age 13, she has come to America to defeat me in court.
Character 3
Name: Max
Description: A "fabulous" magician famed for his aerial illusions. Accused of murder.
Character 4
Name: Regina Berry
Description: The idol of the Berry Big Circus and daughter to Russel Berry, the Ringmaster.
Character 5
Name: Russell Berry
Description: The victim and Ringmaster of the Berry Big Circus. Regina Berry's father.
Character 6
Name: Ben
Description: Real Name: Benjamin Woodman. A ventriloquist. Conversing with him is really tiring.
Character 7
Name: Moe
Description: Real Name: Lawrence Curls. The Ringmaster's old friend, a pleasant stooge of a clown.
Character 8
Name: Acro
Description: Real Name: Ken Dingling. A star acrobat currently undergoing rehabilitation.
Character 9
Name: Bat
Description: Real Name: Sean Dingling. Bit on the head six months ago by Léon. Still in a coma.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Attorney's Badge
Description: It's my all-important badge. It shows that I am a defense attorney.
Evidence 1
Name: Maya's Magatama
Description: Slightly translucent. It radiates softly with a mysterious light.
Evidence 2
Name: Crime Photo
Description: A picture of the crime scene. [caption] A person is lying face down on a big box in the snow. There are footprints leading to where he is.
Evidence 3
Name: Silk Hat
Description: Made-to-order fedora that is a symbol of Max's fabulousness. Found at the crime scene.
Evidence 4
Name: Max G. Promo Poster
Description: Emblazoned with Max's three famous symbols. A silk hat, cloak and white roses.
Evidence 5
Name: Ringmaster's Papers
Description: Documents related to Max's salary negotiations. He got an enormous raise 1 week ago.
Evidence 6
Name: Circus Map
Description: A map of the Berry Big Circus. The circus is depicted on the left. The ring master’s room and cafeteria are on the northeast of the circus. To the right is the lodging house. Moe is on the first floor and Acro is on the third.
Evidence 7
Name: Broken Bottle
Description: An orange juice bottle that was found broken on the cafeteria floor.
Evidence 8
Name: Trilo Quist
Description: A ventriloquist's puppet. An operatic tenor who doubles as Ben's sidekick.
Evidence 9
Name: Money the Monkey
Description: A monkey who takes care of Acro. Habitually gathers all sorts of shiny objects.
Evidence 10
Name: Ring
Description: A cheap ring with an eerie sparkle. "From T to R" is engraved on it.
Evidence 11
Name: Russell's Autopsy Report
Description: Time of death: 10:15 PM. Cause: Blunt force trauma to the back of the head.
Evidence 12
Name: Wooden Box
Description: The victim was hunched over this 20 lb. box. It was locked by a small key.
Evidence 13
Name: Small Seasoning Bottle
Description: Found inside the Wooden Box the victim was hunched over. It contains pepper.
Evidence 14
Name: Grand Prix Photo
Description: Photo of Max's Award Ceremony. Max is standing at the center holding a trophy. Two girls stand to either side. The bust of max is right next to him.
Evidence 15
Name: Max G. Bust
Description: Bronze statue taken from the cafeteria before the crime. It looks rather heavy.
Evidence 16
Name: Note
Description: Posted in the Cafeteria on the day of the crime, then torn. States: "To The Murderer!" Torn by Ringmaster, found in his tailcoat pocket. Reads To The Murderer! You haven't forgotten what happened six months ago, have you? I have conclusive evidence of what took place. Meet at 10:00 PM tonight at the lodging house plaza. Found in Regina's pocket on the morning of crime. Reads To The Murderer! You haven't forgotten what happened six months ago, have you? I have conclusive evidence of what took place. Meet at 10:00 PM tonight at the lodging house plaza. Placed by Acro in Regina's pocket on morning of crime. Reads To The Murderer!

You haven't forgotten what
happened six months ago,
have you? I have conclusive
evidence of what took place.

Meet at 10:00 PM tonight
at the lodging house plaza.

Evidence 17
Name: Stage Costume
Description: A shiny spangled vest. It's not Maya's size at all.
Evidence 18
Name: Léon
Description: The animal show's lion. Shot by the Ringmaster six months ago for biting a performer.
Evidence 19
Name: Scarf
Description: Bat's scarf. Stained with his blood and a small quantity of pepper.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: I suppose I could have lifted something the size of that bust.
Person: Acro
Testimony 1
Testimony: I have a strong upper body from working as an acrobat, and only my legs were injured.
Person: Acro
Testimony 2
Testimony: However, lifting the bust and looking out of the window would've been impossible.
Person: Acro
Testimony 3
Testimony: There's no way I could have exerted that kind of force on my lower body.
Person: Acro
Testimony 4
Testimony: That makes it impossible for me to have known the location of the Ringmaster's head.
Person: Acro
Testimony 5
Testimony: Thus it would be unrealistic to drop the bust on him. Don't you think?
Person: Acro

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Okay, let's see. I need to find a contradiction between one evidence and one testimony. Let me start by going through each testimony and see which evidence might conflict with it.

Looking at the testimonies from Acro (Character 8):

Testimony 0: Acro says he could have lifted the bust because he's strong in the upper body. The bust is heavy, but maybe that's possible. 

Testimony 1: Confirms upper body strength, legs injured. So he can lift but can't move lower body much.

Testimony 2: He couldn't lift the bust and look out the window. Hmm, why? Maybe because of his leg injury?

Testimony 3: Emphasizes that his lower body can't exert force, so he couldn't do both lifting and looking out.

Testimony 4: Therefore, he couldn't know where the Ringmaster's head was to drop the bust on him.

Testimony 5: Concludes it's unrealistic for him to have done the crime.

Now, looking at the evidences. Evidence 15 is the Max G. Bust, described as a bronze statue taken from the cafeteria before the crime, heavy. The cause of death was blunt force trauma to the back of the head. The crime scene had the victim hunched over a box. 

Wait, the key point here is whether Acro could have physically done the act. The testimony says he couldn't because of his legs. But Evidence 15 says the bust is heavy. If Acro's upper body is strong, maybe he could lift it, but the problem is moving or positioning himself to drop it accurately. 

Wait, Testimony 2 says he couldn't lift the bust AND look out the window. But maybe the bust's weight is a factor. Let me check the evidence again. Evidence 12 is the Wooden Box which was 20 lbs. The bust is bronze, so probably heavier. If Acro's upper body can handle the bust, but he can't move his legs, maybe he couldn't position himself to drop it from a height, like from a window. 

Wait, the crime scene is in the snow, so maybe the bust was dropped from above? If Acro was in his room (third floor per Evidence 6: Circus Map says Acro is on the third floor of the lodging house), he might need to go to a window, lift the bust, and drop it precisely. But if his legs are injured, maybe he couldn't stand or move to the window. 

However, the contradiction might be with Evidence 15's description of the bust's weight. If the bust is too heavy for Acro to lift even with his upper body strength, then his testimony that he "could have lifted something the size of that bust" (Testimony 0) would contradict Evidence 15's description of it being heavy. Wait, but the evidence says it's "rather heavy" but doesn't specify if it's beyond Acro's strength. 

Alternatively, maybe there's another evidence. Let me check other evidences. Evidence 19 is Bat's scarf with blood and pepper. Not related. Evidence 12's box was 20 lbs. The bust is bronze, so maybe heavier. 

Wait, Testimony 0 says Acro could have lifted the bust. Evidence 15 just says it's heavy. If the bust's weight is such that even with upper body strength, it's impossible, then that's a contradiction. But the problem is we don't have explicit info on the bust's exact weight. 

Alternatively, looking at Testimony 2 and 3: Acro says he couldn't have done both lifting and looking out the window. But maybe the bust was placed on the box? Or the crime scene's setup required moving it there. Wait, the victim was hunched over the wooden box. If the bust was used as the weapon, perhaps Acro had to carry it to the scene. But if he can't move due to leg injury, that's an issue. 

Alternatively, Evidence 6's circus map shows Acro is on the third floor. If the crime scene is at the lodging house plaza (from the note), then he might need to go downstairs, but with leg injury, he can't. So Testimony 1 says his legs are injured but upper body is strong. If the crime required going downstairs, then he couldn't. But the testimony says he couldn't lift and look out the window. 

Hmm, perhaps the key contradiction is between Testimony 0 where Acro says he could lift the bust, but Evidence 15 says it's a bronze statue (heavy) and the crime required precise action. But without exact weight, maybe that's not the best. 

Wait, looking at Testimony 5: Acro says it's unrealistic to drop the bust on the head. The cause of death was blunt force to the back of the head. If the bust was dropped from above, like from a window, then Acro being on third floor could do that. But he claims he couldn't because he can't move his legs to get to the window? Or couldn't aim. 

Wait, Testimony 2 says he couldn't lift the bust and look out the window. Maybe the act of looking out requires standing or moving, which he can't do because of legs. But if he's in his room, maybe he could still look out without moving much. 

Alternatively, maybe the bust was used to hit the victim while Acro was at the scene. But the victim was found in the snow, so maybe the bust was placed on the box and then pushed? Not sure. 

Alternatively, maybe the contradiction is between Testimony 0 and Evidence 15. If the bust is too heavy for Acro to lift, even with upper body strength, then his testimony that he "could have lifted" contradicts the evidence's description of it being heavy. But "rather heavy" is subjective. 

Alternatively, looking at Testimony 2: he couldn't lift the bust AND look out the window. But maybe the bust's weight is manageable for him, so the problem is the combination. But the evidence doesn't say anything about the window or the action required beyond the bust's weight. 

Hmm, maybe I'm overcomplicating. Let me see other testimonies. The user's previous examples had contradictions where a testimony claimed something impossible based on evidence. 

Wait, the Note (Evidence 16) was placed in Regina's pocket by Acro. If Acro was injured in legs, could he have done that? Evidence 6 says Acro is on third floor. To get to Regina's area, maybe possible. But that's not directly contradicting. 

Alternatively, Testimony 3 says he can't exert force on lower body, so couldn't move. But if the crime required moving the bust to the scene, which is in the plaza, then he couldn't get there. But the bust was in the cafeteria before the crime (Evidence 15 says taken from cafeteria). So maybe the killer took it from there. 

Wait, the crime scene is at the lodging house plaza (from the note's meeting place). The bust was in the cafeteria. So to move it from cafeteria to plaza would require moving it, which Acro might not be able to do if he can't walk. 

But Testimony 0 says he could lift the bust, but maybe couldn't carry it a distance. But the evidence doesn't say the distance. 

Alternatively, maybe the key is that the bust was used to kill the Ringmaster. If Acro couldn't have moved it to the scene because of his legs, then his testimony that he couldn't do it (Testimony 5) is supported, but if the evidence shows he had the opportunity, then contradiction. 

Hmm, maybe I'm missing something. Let me check again. 

Wait, Testimony 2: "However, lifting the bust and looking out of the window would've been impossible." So he's saying that he can't do both actions at the same time. But maybe the crime didn't require looking out the window. Maybe the bust was dropped from the window onto the victim below. If the victim was in the plaza below Acro's window, then Acro would need to lift the bust, go to the window, and drop it. But if he can't move his legs, he can't get to the window. 

So Testimony 3 says he can't exert force on lower body, so can't move to the window. Therefore, he couldn't have done it. But Evidence 15 just describes the bust. 

Alternatively, maybe there's an evidence that shows Acro was seen there. Wait, no. 

Wait, looking at Evidence 19: Bat's scarf with blood and pepper. The victim's autopsy shows cause of death was blunt force, and the small seasoning bottle had pepper. Maybe the pepper is a clue, but not related to Acro's testimony. 

Hmm. Maybe the contradiction is between Testimony 0 and the fact that the bust is too heavy. But without explicit weight, not sure. 

Wait, the user's previous answers often involved testimonies that claimed something was seen or done that evidence shows wasn't possible. For example, in the first problem, the costume had a bullet hole but testimony said no bullet damage. 

In this case, maybe Testimony 0 says Acro could lift the bust, but Evidence 15's description makes it clear that it's impossible. But unless the evidence says it's too heavy for him, maybe not. 

Alternatively, looking at Testimony 5: Acro says it's unrealistic to drop the bust on the head. But if the bust was used to hit the victim from above, maybe the angle or position required precise aim, which Acro couldn't do because he couldn't see where to drop it (if he had to look out the window but couldn't move). 

Wait, the Testimony 2 says he couldn't lift the bust and look out the window. So if the action required both (holding the bust while looking to aim), then he couldn't do it. But the evidence doesn't say he had to do both. 

Alternatively, maybe the key is in the Note (Evidence 16). The note was placed in Regina's pocket by Acro. If Acro couldn't move due to legs, he couldn't have placed the note there. But Testimony doesn't mention that. 

Hmm. I'm stuck. Let me think again. 

Wait, Testimony 0: Acro says he "could have lifted something the size of that bust." The bust is bronze and "rather heavy" (Evidence 15). So if the bust's weight is such that even with upper body strength, he couldn't lift it, then that's a contradiction. But the evidence doesn't state the exact weight. 

Alternatively, maybe the bust's weight is manageable, so his testimony isn't contradicted. 

Wait, another angle: The crime photo (Evidence 2) shows the victim lying on a box in the snow. If the bust was used as the weapon, it must have been present at the scene. But the bust was taken from the cafeteria before the crime (Evidence 15). So someone had to move it. If Acro couldn't move due to legs, he couldn't have transported the bust to the plaza. But if he could lift it (Testimony 0), but couldn't move to carry it there, that's a problem. 

So the contradiction is between Testimony 0 (he could lift it) but Evidence 6's location (he's on third floor, needing to go down, which he can't due to legs) making it impossible to move it to the scene. But that's two evidences, not one. 

Hmm, maybe I need to think differently. Let's see the answer format requires one evidence and one testimony. 

Looking back at previous examples, like when the testimony claimed seeing a symbol but evidence showed it wasn't present. 

Wait, Testimony 0 says Acro could lift the bust. If the bust's weight is such that even with his strength, it's impossible, but the evidence doesn't specify. 

Alternatively, maybe Evidence 15 says the bust was taken from the cafeteria before the crime. So it wasn't there during the crime. Wait, no, the bust was used in the crime. Wait, the description says "taken from the cafeteria before the crime". So the bust was moved from the cafeteria to the crime scene. If Acro had to do that, but couldn't move due to legs, then contradiction between his ability to lift (Testimony 0) but inability to move to transport it (Testimony 3). 

But the contradiction would be between his testimony about lifting and the evidence that moving it required more than just lifting. 

Alternatively, maybe the key is in Testimony 2 and 3. He says he can't lift the bust and look out the window. But if the crime didn't require looking out, then it's not a contradiction. 

Hmm. I'm not sure. Maybe I should look for another angle. 

Wait, the note (Evidence 16) was placed in Regina's pocket by Acro. If Acro was injured and couldn't move, he couldn't have done that. So Testimony 0 (he could lift the bust) but the evidence that he placed the note (which requires movement) would be a contradiction. But the testimony doesn't mention the note. 

Alternatively, the note was placed by Acro according to the evidence description, so if Acro couldn't move, that's a contradiction between Evidence 16 (he placed it) and Testimony 3 (he can't move lower body). 

Ah! That might be it. 

Evidence 16 states that the note was placed in Regina's pocket by Acro on the morning of the crime. 

But Testimony 3 says Acro couldn't exert force on his lower body, implying he couldn't move around. If placing the note required him to move to Regina's location (maybe in another part of the circus), then his inability to move contradicts the evidence that he placed the note. 

So the contradiction is between Evidence 16 (Acro placed the note) and Testimony 3 (he couldn't move due to legs). 

So the pair would be Evidence 16 and Testimony 3. 

Wait, let me confirm. 

Testimony 3: "There's no way I could have exerted that kind of force on my lower body." 

If placing the note required moving, then Testimony 3's claim that he couldn't move his legs would contradict Evidence 16 which says he did place the note. 

Yes, that makes sense. So the answer is {"evidence":16, "testimony":3}. 

But wait, let me check previous examples. In the first problem, the user had a similar setup where a testimony claimed they couldn't have been there, but evidence showed they were. Here, the evidence says Acro placed the note, but his testimony says he couldn't move, so he couldn't have placed it. That's a direct contradiction.
